The Nurse and Health Care Worker Protection Act of 2013 is aimed at addressing musculoskeletal disorders among healthcare workers, particularly nurses and nursing assistants. Patient lifting, transferring, and repositioning injuries are identified as the leading cause of these injuries, posing a significant risk to the employees' health and welfare. The physical demands of the nursing profession, particularly patient lifting, transferring, and repositioning, lead to a high rate of injuries among healthcare workers. Many nurses suffer from chronic back pain, with a significant percentage requiring leave from work, resulting in a material impairment of their health. Patients are safer when lifted using mechanical lift programs, reducing injuries like skin tears and pressure ulcers. This also decreases the risk of patients being dropped during care. Assistive patient handling is crucial for patient safety. The development of assistive patient handling technology has reduced injuries among nursing staff and patients, making manual patient handling outdated in many healthcare facilities. Patient handling technology and practices have led to a significant decrease in injuries among nursing staff and healthcare workers. This has resulted in reduced lost work days, staff turnover, and workers' compensation costs for musculoskeletal disorders. Several states have also implemented safe patient handling measures. Studies have shown that assistive patient handling technology reduces workers' compensation costs for musculoskeletal disorders. Some States have implemented safe patient handling standards, demonstrating the feasibility of such programs. Establishing safe patient handling standards for healthcare workers is critical for protecting their health and safety. Establishing safe patient handling standards for healthcare workers, including direct-care registered nurses, is crucial for protecting their health and safety, addressing the nursing shortage, and improving patient safety. The Safe Patient Handling, Mobility, and Injury Prevention Standard is established to protect healthcare workers, including registered nurses, and improve patient safety in facilities receiving Medicare and Medicaid funds. The Secretary of Labor must promulgate an interim final standard on safe patient handling, mobility, and injury prevention within 1 year of the enactment of the Act to prevent musculoskeletal disorders for healthcare workers. The safe patient handling, mobility, and injury prevention standard must be finalized within 2 years of the Act's enactment. It will require the use of engineering controls to prevent injuries from manual patient handling by healthcare workers. The prevention standard mandates the use of engineering controls and mechanical technology to reduce injuries from manual patient handling by healthcare workers. If mechanical technology is not feasible, alternative controls like trained lift teams must be utilized to minimize injury risks. The standard requires healthcare employers to implement safe patient handling programs, including trained lift teams, to reduce injury risks for nurses and healthcare workers. The Social Security Act is amended to include safe patient handling, mobility, and injury prevention standards in facilities receiving Medicare and Medicaid funds. The amendments specify the effective date for these standards to be implemented in health care facilities. SEC. 4. NONPREEMPTION. Effect on Other Laws: This Act does not preempt state laws unless they conflict with this Act. It also does not diminish states' authority to enact laws providing equal or greater protections for employees. Rights of health care workers are retained under this Act. The Act does not diminish the rights of health care workers under any Federal or State law or collective bargaining agreement. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS.
